person.persName: Winfield Scott (New York City, New York, Commanding general United States Army)

body.p: New York City, New York, commanding general United States Army. Virginia native. Son of Ann Mason Scott and William Scott. Married Maria Mayo Scott on March 11, 1817 in Virginia. Father of Maria Mayo Scott, John Scott, Virginia Scott, Edward Winfield Scott, Cornelia Winfield Scott, Adeline Camilla Scott, and Marcela Scott. Graduate of the College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia in 1805. Commissioned as Captain of light infantry in 1808. Promoted to Lieutenant Colonel during the War of 1812. Received a brevet promotion to Major General in 1814. Authored General Regulations for The Army; or Military Institutes in 1821. Received full promotion to Major General and commanding general of the United States Army in 1841. Unsuccessful Whig Party candidate for President of the United States in 1848 and 1852. Promoted to Brevet Lieutenant General on March 7, 1855. Resigns as general-in-chief of the United States Army on November 1, 1861.
